participants.participant: Christine Ritz, Group Head of Investor Relations
Dipl. Wirtsch.-Ing. Hans Dieter Pötsch, Functional Responsibility, Finance and Controlling
Detlef Wittig, Executive Vice President, Group Sales and Marketing

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to today's Volkswagen AG half year 2009 results conference call. For your information, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to your host today, Ms. Christine Ritz, Group Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, madam.

Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Volkswagen's conference call for the results of the first half of 2009. I am joined today by Hans Dieter Pötsch, Member of the Board of Management, Volkswagen AG, responsible for Finance and Controlling; and by Detlef Wittig, Executive Vice President, Volkswagen AG, responsible for Group Sales and Marketing.

As usual, you can also follow the webcast and download the chart from our website www.volkswagenag.com/ir. Questions can be sent by email or called in. Before we start, I would like to mention that after the speech of Mr. Pötsch and Mr. Wittig, we will first respond to the questions of analysts and later answer those of journalists.
I would now like to ask Mr. Pötsch to give a few comments before Mr. Wittig goes into detail of the delivering to customers. Mr. Pötsch, please.

Thank you frau Ritz, ladies and gentlemen, also a warm welcome from my side to this conference call. As you all know, the Supervisory Boards of both Volkswagen and Porsche have agreed upon the creation of an integrated automotive group of Volkswagen and Porsche. This will build on the achievement and history of both companies leading to a stronger, more competitive, integrated automotive group. We fully respect the traditions and history of the iconic Porsche brand. Together with Volkswagen, Porsche has great potential and will become even more successful creating new jobs in the process. Porsche's independence within the Group is assured. Together we are now working on the final concept covering topics such as the detailed evaluations to take the next steps forward. We anticipate a progressive participation of Volkswagen in Porsche AG, the operating company; leading to a merger of Volkswagen and Porsche SE at a future date.

Much work needs to be done to achieve these objectives and I would ask for a little patience from your side while we work through the detail. What I can assure you is that we will at all times keep you informed as and when decisions are made. Speaking for Volkswagen, I want to make it absolutely clear that the decisions taken will help to make Volkswagen stronger and more profitable. In addition, we know how important our strong financial position is in securing funding for our financial services activities and we will do all that we can to hold on to our competitiveness in this field.

Let me now turn to our report on the first six months. The worldwide financial crisis has continued to impact the global auto industry in particular. The Volkswagen Group performed significantly better than the overall market posting deliveries down 4.4% for the first six months supported by the scrapping incentive here in Germany and positive government actions in China and Brazil in particular. While, of course, we welcome these actions, they hint to a weaker underlying demand, which will be evidenced as we move into 2010. Operating profit for the first six months proved resilient and came in at €1.2 billion despite the tough market environment.

For the second quarter, which for seasonality reasons is typically our strongest quarter, the operating profit was €928 million. The financial result of negative 437 million reflects in part a lower contribution from the companies we consolidate at equity, plus the impact of lower interest rates on firstly, the returns on our cash balance and also the discounting of long-term provisions. With a negative financial result, profit before tax came in at €803 million.

The current uncertain global environment -- cash remains king and we have worked hard to reduce stocks further to improve working capital. Automotive net cash flow was strongly positive and automotive liquidity improved to €12.3 billion. Now, I would like to hand over to Mr. Wittig, who will take you through our sales development. Mr. Wittig, over to you.

Thank you Mr. Pötsch, welcome also from my side. Ladies and gentlemen, as we all know, developments on the global financial markets clearly impacted negatively the world car markets starting in the second half of 2008 and still continuing in the first half of this year. On this chart here, the world car market, you can see the development of the market this year, by months and also by quarter, in comparison to the previous year. After a monumental loss of 21% in the first quarter, cumulative, the world car market shows statistically the first signs of relief falling only by minus 14% in the second quarter. And you can see on the chart, June, with a minus of only 9% compared with last year. This leads to a decline of 17% or 18% in the first half year. But I have to add a note of caution here however. As the car market started to decline from May last year. Statistically, the comparison with last year's figures will show signs of improvement, while in reality the markets continue on a low level result really recovering. However, on a positive side, we also take note that there are first and strong signals of recovery in China; the mark went up by plus 30% in India and also in Brazil.

On the next chart we can compare our performance, our deliveries to customers with the trend of the world car market, and in contrast to the total car market our Group deliveries to customers recorded a visible upturn. Under these circumstances we clearly continued to performance comparatively well. For the first time this year, in May deliveries to customers showed a positive year-on-year performance and growth accelerated in June. In last month we sold 6.5% more cars than the months of the previous year and which led to a positive result for the second quarter, you can see this on the chart, in the second quarter we recorded 1.4% more sales than last year.

All in all, in the first half year, our deliveries to customers with a minus of 4% were better than the car market. Car market at minus 17, minus 18%, clearly supported by the scrappage incentive in the German market, our sales went up by 19% in Germany as well as by the positive developments in China and also in Brazil. As a result, we are gaining market share globally.

The next chart demonstrates our global performance by area and it is obvious that we outperform the total car market in all world areas. To the left on the chart you can see North America and to the right, up to the right, Central and Eastern Europe, these markets were hit most. And the total markets there contracted by 33% in North America and 45% in Central and Eastern Europe. While our deliveries to customers decreased by only 12% in North America and 28% in Eastern Europe. We did especially well in Russia, where the market is cut by half actually, and we improved to a position number four, to rank number four in the Russian car market by now.

The Western European markets in the center, up there. The market shows a downturn of minus 9.8, minus 10% and our deliveries were down by minus 8% suffering mainly from short supply and particularly due to the Polo model generation change. However, with this performance we are also gaining market share in Western Europe. And with the startup of production of the new Polo, our supply situation has improved considerably and we will be able to further improve in the second half of the year. In the two regions Asia Pacific and South America, the Volkswagen Group performed very successfully, expanded sales by 18.9% in Asia Pacific and with 0.1% in South America and this was certainly driven in those areas by China on the one hand and Brazil on the other hand.

Now turning once more to the deliveries by market areas. Again, as the total result tells us compared to previous year the deliveries to customers of our Group decreased by minus 4.4%, down to 3.1 million cars and with 3.1 million cars sold we continue to get closer to our next targeted competitor, General Motors. They published their sales figures, their deliveries to customers at 3.5 million units, and also closer to Toyota and Toyota recorded 3.6 million cars.

In Western Europe, our deliveries declined by 8%. In contrast, deliveries in Germany were up 18.5% supported, as mentioned before, by the government's scrapping incentive program. In Eastern Europe and in North America and in South America, we saw two-digit numbers of decline of our sales volume explained in the previous chart already. And finally, in both South America and in Asia Pacific we were able to increase our sales over previous year's results.

Now looking at the individual brands of the Group. First of all, all our volume passenger car brands did better than the car growth market. And first of all, Volkswagen Passenger Car is our strongest brand, rebounded and sold 2.2% more cars than last year with a number up to 1,949,000 units driven by strong demand in Germany and France, and also in Russia and Poland, and naturally as mentioned before in Brazil and in China. And out of the Volkswagen range of models Golf, Tiguan and the Brazilian Lavida and the Chinese Lavida enjoyed a great acceptance in the public. So the Volkswagen brand enjoyed a rather favorable product mix and at the same time a rather favorable market mix.

Audi's deliveries were down by minus 9.7%, down to 466,000 cars. This is certainly due to the downsizing impact on the premium segment. However, Audi did comparatively well and outperformed the direct premium competitors and gained market position in that segment substantially. And certainly the addition of the Q5 to the Audi range also helped to achieve this result.

Škoda's deliveries did decrease by 10%, down to 329,000 cars. Due to weak Central and Eastern European markets, Škoda, for instance in the Eastern European markets went down by 31% while the market was down by 45%. So the Eastern markets is the home ground of Škoda being rather weak and also certainly due to the strong Czech corona.

SEAT suffered a decline of 15%, considering that the Spanish market was down by more than 38%, this is still a reasonable good performance. SEAT bus is also gaining market share in Europe and recaptured the number one position in the Spanish market. Bentley was down 52% in the first half year due to the weak luxuries segments, especially in the United States and also in the United Kingdom.

Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles deliveries to customers declined by 31% down to 179,000 units in a very weak light commercial market in Europe, the market in Europe is down by 30%. We have to consider, when we look at the Commercial Vehicles sales numbers here, we have to consider that last year the truck and bus business, which we sold in the meantime to MAN, was included in the figures, the 263,000 cars last year included 30,000 cars in the truck and bus area.

I would like to show you also the development of our total new car stocks worldwide because of the importance of the inventory management and its financial impact on stock development. At the end of 2008 our actual stock, which includes both new car inventory at factory and wholesale level, plus at those at dealer level. So the actual stock was at a level of 1.2 million cars then, nearly a quarter above our ideal stock level. Due to the cut of product in the first quarter and further sales activities to reduce inventory, we achieved a balance situation already by the end of the first quarter, we reduced the stock level by 140,000 cars and since then we managed to lower even further the actual stock situation down to a level of roughly 900,000 cars. And regarding our closely monitored sales and production planning process we will be able to maintain this level during the remainder of the year 2009.

Now to finish a few highlights on some of our new models which we launched just recently. Those models have contributed to the Group sales success in the first half of this year and provides a strong basis also for our second half year sales performance. On top to the left, the new Polo; internally the A05, the fifth generation of Polo offers the best combination of quality and driving pleasure. In this segment the excellent feedback from our customers was affirmed by close to 40,000 customer orders that we received in Germany so far, exceeding our expectations by far. And in the second half, by the end of the second half of this year in November we will add to the Polo range the three-door version as well. The Audi A5 Sportback is our new five door coupe, was recently shown on the occasion of the 100 anniversary of Audi. It is a new beautiful design, fusing the emotionality of a coupe with the functionality of a five-door car; market introduction will be in September.

Next Škoda, the Škoda Yeti, here we can simply say this Yeti is compact, likeable, and strong, and had an exceptional positive feedback of, at both press and dealer presentations. We expect the Yeti to become very successful with market introduction starting in August next month. Finally SEAT, the SEAT Exeo ST, sports tour wagon, derivative, complements the Exeo limousine and this is SEAT's first entry to the B-class car segment offering high quality, proven technology, with style and performance, and this SEAT Exeo version has started already early this month. So far for the market presentation, I'd like to return to Mrs. Ritz, please.
Thank you, Mr. Wittig. Mr. Pötsch, can you take us through the financials please?

Yes, of course I can and let's get started with sales. Revenue, sales revenue, which as you know excludes our Chinese joint ventures which we report at equity in the financial results fell by 9.4% to €51 billion. Scania, by the way, contributed €3.1 billion to sales revenues, meaning that on a like-for-like basis the reduction in revenue was even greater, highlighting the dramatic impact of weak global markets.

Looking at the details, the drop in sales volume translated into a negative impact of €8.1 billion on sales revenue. Price was positive at 0.3 billion, while strong sales in Germany only partially compensated for deterioration in the overall mix for a net minus €0.5 billion. The U.K. pound and Brazilian real in particular, led to a net negative of €0.8 billion on currency. Our Financial Services division reported an improvement of €0.7 billion owing to higher sales of leased vehicles.

Now let's move to operating profit. Operating profit declined to €1.2 billion, that's down 2.2 billion on the first six months of 2008. Unsurprisingly, given the sales figures we have reported, volume, price, and mix had a significantly negative impact with currency proving a further break on our performance of a combined €3.3 billion. Our intense focus on costs continues both with respect to our products but also with our overheads, which led to a combined improvement of €0.9 billion. Now that we no longer include the earnings from Volkswagen heavy trucks in Brazil, as we sold our facility in Resende, the net positive impact is €0.5 billion.

Showing resilience in the face of a dramatic slowdown in the heavy truck market, Scania came in with a small positive result before the purchase price accounting adjustments resulted in a small loss. And to complete this chart, Financial Services reported a declined of €0.2 billion.

The next two charts focus on the cash flow and liquidity of the Automotive Division. Operating cash flow improved 27.2% to €6.5 billion. This positive performance is substantially related to a dramatic improvement in working capital of €3 billion related in particular to the reduction in our inventories as Mr. Wittig earlier explained. Our CapEx ratio stands at 5.6%, while the lower revenue impacts the calculation here, it is more significantly also an indication of how we have continued to invest in our new plants in the U.S., in India, and Russia as well as in our multi-award winning powertrain, not to forget exciting new models such as the new Polo, launched on the market this year and next.

The world will emerge from recession and we are determined to continue to invest in the future. Investments we are making now will pay off when economy does start recovering. For the first six months of 2009, our reported cash flow from investing activities stood at a net €2.2 billion. Together, net cash flow for the Automotive Division was a positive €4.3 billion.

Now let's turn to liquidity. The improvement in operating cash flow together with lower cash flows from investing activities due to the inflow of funds relating to the sale of our Brazilian truck business, resulted in a further improvement in the liquidity of the Automotive Division. As at June 30, automotive net liquidity stood at €12.3 billion. That's up over €4 billion versus year-end 2008.

Gross liquidity for the Group stood at €28 billion at the end of the first half. This strong financial base will ensure that we have the ability to face the challenge of uncertain capital and sales markets while we continue to invest in our future.

Now, moving on now to the financial performance of our nine brands. Earnings declined across all of our brands with the exception of commercial vehicles, which benefited from the sale of our activities in Resende resulting in a net plus of €463 million. Volkswagen Cars turned around the loss in the first quarter to a positive situation and reported a six-month profit of €260 million benefiting in particular from the pick up in sales in Germany and Brazil.

Audi's operating result was very impressive; €823 million with a strong margin of 5.7% for the first half, and so far demonstrating the robustness of their business model, the strength of their product portfolio, and the ingenuity of their modular engineering systems. Similarly, Škoda posted a strong margin of 5.8% in the second quarter for an average of 4.1% for the first six months, equating to a positive operating result of €135 million. Good sales performance and higher margin markets were important contributors to this performance. SEAT continues to suffer from the collapse in demand in their home market and showed a loss in this period.

Given the exceptionally tough heavy truck market, Scania showed a remarkable positive of €48 million and as I said before that's the number before purchase price allocation. Financial Services reported €321 million, that's down 200 million on first half of 2008. And finally, our sales in China grew robustly in the first half such that our joint ventures recorded a proportional operating profit of €294 million, that's up 60% on the prior year.

Now this leads me to our 2009 outlook, which you can read in detail in the interim report. And as I said at the Q1 call, with our strong brands and young fuel-efficient model range, the Volkswagen Group is clearly demonstrating that it is well prepared for the current economic and market situation. For this reason, we believe that the Volkswagen Group will perform better than the market as a whole and will be able to gain market share during the crisis.

The Group's sales revenue in 2009 will be lower than in the previous year and rising refinancing costs and worsening mix will serve as an additional drag on earnings. We'll counter this trend in particular, through disciplined cost and investment management and to continue the optimization of our processes within our 18 plus strategy.

The high volatility of market development does not commit any reliable forecast to be made for the rest of fiscal year 2009. However, based on the extremely weak business in the first six months of 2009, we continue to expect that our earnings will not reach the level of previous years. In the face of these challenges we expect the Volkswagen Group to close 2009 with a profit.

Allow me here to make a short comment on 2010. While we anticipate that some markets will show growth, this will be balanced by others, where amongst other issues, government support schemes will end, leading us to expect no significant increase in demand in 2010. Ladies and gentlemen, we continue to face unprecedented challenges in the markets. However, I strongly believe that the results I have discussed with you today clearly demonstrate; firstly, the success of our brand strategy; secondly, that the excellent diversity of our global sales is enabling us to balance our geographic exposure; and thirdly, that the improving efficiency of our business is delivering profitable results in the face of an enduring global recession. We know that we have more to do but we believe we are on the right path. As we continue to invest, we will emerge from the recession stronger with exciting new cars married to ever more efficient powertrains ready to meet the challenges of the future.

Volkswagen Group, together with Porsche, is on the path to a sustainable profitable future. I am convinced that with our solid financial foundation we have the right strategies for the challenges of today, but more importantly, also of tomorrow. We believe we can build our company into the most profitable and successful integrated automotive group, Volkswagen and Porsche, together on the path to continued success.
Mr. Pötsch, thank you very much. We will now move to the Q&A session starting first with the questions from analysts.
Thank you. The question and answer section will be conducted electronically. We will pause for just a moment to allow everyone to signal for questions.
Thank you very much. Let's have the first question please.
Our first question is from Gregor Claussen from Commerzbank. Please go ahead.

Yeah, good afternoon. Thank you for taking my questions. I have three if I may. The first was regarding free cash flow development. Do you think that positive free cash flow in H2 is possible or do you think a negative free cash flow is more likely as destocking in H1 seems to be completed, if I got that right?

The second question is maybe a few words on the liquidity in the Auto Division, especially the amount of credit lines and how much is drawn, if you can say that, and can you tell us anything about your refinancing needs in 2009 and 2010?

And the third question if possible, if you just mentioned something regarding the end of scrapping incentives beginning next year. Did I understand this right that you forecast zero percent growth in 2010 compared to 2009? Thank you very much.

Thank you very much. So, we have three questions from Gregor. So the first question is, if we can give some more information about the cash flow development in H2, if we can expect a free cash flow, a positive free cash flow in the second half of this year. Then the second question you are asking if we can give some details on the liquidity and our credit line and our refinancing needs in 2009 and 10. And the last question is about the scrapping incentive, what do we expect for 2010. Will these incentives continue or not. Thank you very much.

If you permit, I will start with answering or trying to answer the third question, zero growth in 2010? We do know that the scrappage incentives schemes will have an end, some by the end of this year, some by middle of next year, some going till the end of next year. But in any case, the major push that we have seen, especially in the European markets, will end some time early next year.

So just as an example, what we do expect that the German market, the German car market will arrive at a level this year of some, say 3.7 million cars. The earlier expectation before we started into this year was 2.7 million, 2.8 million cars. And given that, we can simply say that the German market will return to a level of 2.6, 2.7, maybe 2.8 million cars next year. So we will see a drop in the German market of close to one million cars next year.

Overall, taking the two years into consideration, Germany will in any case benefit and the German car market will benefit from the incentive scheme, but next year the German market will go down. Similar trends we will see in France and maybe in the U.K. So as far as the European market is concerned, we expect a lower total market next year as compared with this year. This may be balanced off by the positive trends in China for instance, and in Brazil, if also Brazil continues the incentive program. So, all in all, we expect more or less a zero growth as far as the world market is concerned next year. Europe, especially Germany going down, other emerging markets are sort of recovering, all in all a zero growth, which does not indicate our expectations as to our growth rate.

Okay, I would like to continue with the question on free cash flow and clearly our goal is to generate a significant positive net cash flow for the full year, of course. And also referring to our unspecified, let me put it that way, outlook statements on for the profit development. We also have to admit there is some uncertainty on the cash flow side. It should, however, be clear that we are continuing on with our significant movements in terms of bringing the investment level to a level which is more adequate to the sales volume and of course also by continuing our efforts to create a better efficiency for the company. We're also supporting a positive cash flow development and clearly the stock levels are one important element, but there are other areas also, so there is, it is still possible to release further amount out of working capital for the remainder of this year.

Then I would like to continue with the question on liquidity and credit lines. In this context I should say that we are having credit lines available of more than €20 billion and most of these lines are undrawn
Yeah, that was very clear. Thank you very much for that.
So, let's have the next question please.
Our next question is from Horst Schneider from HSBC. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Horst Schneider from HSBC. Three questions if I may. The first one is again a follow up question on the outlook for H2 2009, just to get a better feeling where we are in the next two quarters, would it be right to assume that the second quarter in 2009 was probably the strongest quarter in terms of profitability, or is there any chance that Q4 will be even stronger?

Then, second question is regarding the PPA depreciation resulting from Scania, you are not showing that in your quarterly report and I would be interested if you could give any indication what was the PPA depreciation in the first half of 2009 and maybe you could provide also an update on the outlook of the depreciation issue?

And third question is regarding your production plans for the third quarter; you should have by now pretty detailed plans for the Q3 production. So I would be interested if there are any planned shut downs in Q3 and maybe you could provide also an outlook for the fourth quarter on production volumes, thank you.

Thank you very much. Horst has three questions for us. The first question relates to the outlook 2009, if we can explain or if we can give some more information, if the second quarter is our strongest quarter, what do we have to expect in the upcoming quarters. Second question is the PPA for Scania, if you can given some more information what – how much is the PPA effect in the first half of this year and probably we can give an outlook for the full year. The third question refers to our production plans for the third quarter and for the rest of this year. Thank you.

So to the question whether the second quarter was the strongest quarter. I think in principle terms, first of all, if were talking a normal year then as the term says normally the second quarter is indeed the strongest quarter, purely the seasonally and normally also on the basis of a higher number of working days. So, in principle terms this also should hold true in this year of course. Saying that means that that's always on the basis of a very cautious economical outlook and I think from today's point of view we clearly have to say there are only very little, more weaker than stronger signs, that we might see any mentionable recovery through the remainder of the year. So that should mean that the second quarter indeed also for 2009 should remain the strongest quarter profit wise.

Second question as far as the PPA effect is concerned in rough terms, we would assume anything around 200 million for the full year, as the PPA effect and the number for next year should be in the same category. And while I am talking about the number this is an after-tax number.

Now, to the third question on production schemes; you certainly have recognized that the relative development of production in the first six months compared with the year 2008 development was much more pronounced than, for example, deliveries to customers, as an example. And this of course means as we have brought stock levels to a more ideal situation that we have to step up production in a certain way. Already in the third quarter and also the relative development should also be less pronounced in the fourth quarter compared with the first half of the year.

Let me just remind you that as we were a little bit overstocked at the end of 2008, we took a few very significant cuts in terms of production capacity in the first quarter, so that's something, of course, on a cumulative basis we are carrying through the year. It also means that as stock levels are more normalized now, we have to bring production on to a level which is more consistent with the deliveries we execute to the customers.
All right, thank you.
Let's have the next question, please.
Our next question is from Thierry Huon from Exane BNP Paribas. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. This is Thierry Huon speaking from Exane BNP Paribas. One question about the preferred shares. I think it's not possible at this stage to make any right issue without having the approval of extraordinary shareholders' meeting; could you confirm this point? And to indicate if you need to have the approval of the shareholders of the pref or it could be voted, should be voted well, from the shareholders of the ordinary shares. This is my first question.
And the second one is about the impact of the scrapping measures in Germany. Do you have any ideas of the number of cars that you have sold during the first half thanks to this scheme? Thank you.

Okay, thank you, Thierry. You have two questions for us. The first question is if we can comment on a possible capital increase and you would like to know if the preferred shareholders have to approve such an approach, such a decision. The next question is about the impact of the scrapping incentives in Germany if we can give some more details here. Thank you.

I will take the last question first. I think it's better to compare order entry volume rather than delivery to customer volume because, as I mentioned earlier, with the demand going up so quickly in Germany no one of the manufacturers really was able to follow this immediately. So when I look at the order entry numbers that we had in the first half year in Germany on Group level, we had roughly, say 800,000 orders taken of which were half of them based on the scrappage incentive program. So 50% of the orders came in based on the scrappage incentive. And this is certainly a high number but quite obviously customers saw a chance to make their dream come true and now being able to buy instead of a used car a new Volkswagen, or a new Škoda, or a new SEAT.

Okay, let me refer to your question of capital increasing. I should say at the beginning that the answer is, and you allow me to say the question is on a pure hypothetical basis because we'll not give the impression that there is anything concrete because there is no decisions made on any of these points. But essentially based on our current articles of association, the Board of Management is authorized, of course with the consent of the Supervisory Board, to increase the share capital and that's possible until early 2011, by the issue of new ordinary bearer shares against cash, and respectively, or non-cash contributions on one or even several occasions and that's what we have available currently. Any other change of Volkswagen's capital structure, which means additional shares, ordinary and/or preferred shares would require the approval of a shareholder meeting.
Thank you very much.
Yeah, if I may, I would like to know if for the preferred shares you need the approval of the general assembly of the ordinary shareholders or also from the preferred shareholders?

We will try to consult with the lawyers to give you an answer if it's not possible during this meeting, we'll give you a call on this. As you recognize, it's obviously an issue we don't deal with currently.
Okay. Thank you very much, I really appreciate.
So, and the next question please.
Our next question is from Christian Breitsprecher from Oppenheim Research. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, it's Christian Breitsprecher from Oppenheim. I have a question regarding the financing needs when you take over the Porsche AG. You said that keeping a good credit rating is critical for you. First of all, do you mean to say that you want to keep your current credit rating for sure, or would it be enough for you just to keep an investment grade credit rating? And secondly, what would be kind of the minimum net liquidity that you would see as a requirement for Volkswagen to retain?

Okay thank you very much, Christian. Christian has one question for us, whether we can update our financing needs when we would like to take over or to take a stake in Porsche AG. Christian wants to know if we want to keep our current credit rating and what is our minimum net liquidity, which we have in our mind. Thank you.

First of all, I think I was asking for a little patience until we of course will be very willing to talk about also a number of details of any transaction structure. But I do not want to talk about any single details as long as we're not able to present a clear complete transaction model. But in principle terms, answering your question, it is very clear, we think we cannot compromise on the rating issue and that's a very fundamental point.

And your question on the liquidity. I think if you, if I can remind you to that. If we go back a number of months or two or three years when Volkswagen was sitting on, I think it was somewhere around four or five billion automotive liquidity, you and your friends were always asking me on what the hell we would do with the money. Now, surprisingly in the last period I didn't receive too many questions on that, and that's exactly why I think we should be very cautious in analytically identifying or trying to identify any number which might be on certain premises, the appropriate number as long as nobody can tell us on whether the reality just follows the premises.
Well, let's have the next question please.
Our next question is from John Lawson from Citi. Please go ahead.

Thanks very much. I would like first to follow up Thierry's question to Mr. Wittig about the orders under the scrapping scheme in Germany. Mr. Wittig, can you actually tell us how many of the 400,000 orders that you took have actually been delivered and how many are sitting in a bank waiting to be delivered? And we've heard from some of your peers of a little pricing pressure developing perhaps in the second half. I wondered whether your experience had shown any signs of softening prices as far as the second half is concerned.

And then I'd like to come to the VW Bank direct deposit business, which I noticed, Mr. Pötsch, had soared to 19 billion of deposits in the quarter. I guess that one or more of your German peers has also recorded some pretty spectacular growth in this area. It's beginning to look like the German car companies are basically competing with each other for the available pool of deposits. I see a bit of it's beyond one year. I just wondered whether you could update us on the strategy here, since everything seems to have been a bit fast moving. Thanks.

Okay, thank you very much, John. You have two questions for us, one is for Mr. Wittig. You would like to have some more information about the impact of the scrapping scheme on our deliveries in Germany. So, how many cars of the total number of roughly 400,000 are already delivered and you would be happy if we can give some more information about our pricing policy. The next question is for Mr. Pötsch about the business at our VW Bank and the direct deposit business, if we can give an update on our strategy here. Thank you.

Okay.
